text:
The sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn—

(Now he was the firstborn, but when he defiled his father’s bed, his rights as firstborn were given to the sons of Joseph, Israel’s son. So Reuben is not listed as firstborn in the genealogical records.
Though Judah was the strongest among his brothers and a leader descended from him, the right of the firstborn belonged to Joseph.)
The sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
The descendants of Joel: his son Shemaiah, his son Gog, his son Shimei,

his <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> <st data-num="04318" class="">Micah</st>, his <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> <st data-num="07211" class="">Reaiah</st>, his <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> <st data-num="01168" class="">Baal</st>,
and his son Beerah, whom King Tiglath-Pileser of Assyria carried into exile. Beerah was the tribal leader of Reuben.

His brothers by their clans, as listed in their genealogical records:

The leader Jeiel, Zechariah,

and Bela son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel.

They lived in Aroer as far as Nebo and Baal Meon.

In the <st data-num="04217" class="">east</st> they <st data-num="03427" class="">settled</st> <st data-num="05704" class="">as far as</st> the <st data-num="0935" class="">entrance</st> to the <st data-num="04057" class="">wilderness</st> that <st data-num="04480" class="">stretches to</st> the <st data-num="06578" class="">Euphrates</st> <st data-num="05104" class="">River</st>, <st data-num="03588" class="">for</st> their <st data-num="04735" class="">cattle</st> had <st data-num="07235" class="">increased in numbers</st> in the <st data-num="0776" class="">land</st> of <st data-num="01568" class="">Gilead</st>.
During the time of Saul they attacked the Hagrites and defeated them. They took over their territory in the entire eastern region of Gilead.
The descendants of Gad lived near them in the land of Bashan, as far as Salecah.
They included Joel the leader, Shapham the second-in-command, Janai, and Shaphat in Bashan.
Their relatives, listed according to their families, included Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber—seven in all.
These were the sons of Abihail son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz.

<st data-num="0277" class="">Ahi</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="05661" class="">Abdiel</st>, <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="01476" class="">Guni</st>, was the <st data-num="07218" class="">leader</st> of the <st data-num="01004 01">family</st>.<n id="1" />

They <st data-num="03427" class="">lived</st> in <st data-num="01568" class="">Gilead</st>, in <st data-num="01316" class="">Bashan</st> and its <st data-num="01323" class="">surrounding settlements</st>, and <st data-num="03605" class="">in</st> the <st data-num="04054" class="">pasturelands</st> of <st data-num="08289" class="">Sharon</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">to</st> their very <st data-num="08444" class="">borders</st>.<n id="1" />
All of them were listed in the genealogical records in the time of King Jotham of Judah and in the time of King Jeroboam of Israel.
The Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh had 44,760 men in their combined armies, warriors who carried shields and swords, were equipped with bows, and were trained for war.

They <st data-num="06213 04421 05973">attacked</st><n id="1" /> the <st data-num="01905" class="">Hagrites</st>, <st data-num="03195" class="">Jetur</st>, <st data-num="05305" class="">Naphish</st>, and <st data-num="05114" class="">Nodab</st>.

They <st data-num="05826" class="">received</st> divine <st data-num="05826" class="">help</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">in fighting</st> them, and the <st data-num="01905" class="">Hagrites</st> and <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> their <st data-num="05973" class="">allies</st> were <st data-num="05414" class="">handed</st> <st data-num="03027" class="">over</st> to them. They <st data-num="02199" class="">cried out</st> to <st data-num="03588 0430">God</st> during the <st data-num="04421" class="">battle</st>; he <st data-num="06279" class="">responded to</st> their <st data-num="06279" class="">prayers</st> <st data-num="03588" class="">because</st> they <st data-num="0982" class="">trusted</st> in him.<n id="1" />

They <st data-num="07617" class="">seized</st> the Hagrites’<n id="1" /> <st data-num="04735" class="">animals</st>, including <st data-num="02572 0505">50,000</st> <st data-num="01581" class="">camels</st>, <st data-num="03967 02572 0505">250,000</st> <st data-num="06629" class="">sheep</st>, and <st data-num="0505" class="">2,000</st> <st data-num="02543" class="">donkeys</st>. They also took captive <st data-num="03967 0505">100,000</st> <st data-num="05315 0120">people</st>.
Because God fought for them, they killed many of the enemy. They dispossessed the Hagrites and lived in their land until the exile.
The half-tribe of Manasseh settled in the land from Bashan as far as Baal Hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon. They grew in number.

These were the leaders of their families:

Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel. They were skilled warriors, men of reputation, and leaders of their families.

But they <st data-num="04603" class="">were unfaithful</st> to the <st data-num="0430" class="">God</st> of their <st data-num="01" class="">ancestors</st><n id="1" /> and <st data-num="02181 0310">worshiped instead</st><n id="2" /> the <st data-num="0430" class="">gods</st> of the <st data-num="0776" class="">native</st> <st data-num="05971" class="">peoples</st><n id="3" /> <st data-num="0834" class="">whom</st> <st data-num="0430" class="">God</st> had <st data-num="08045" class="">destroyed</st> <st data-num="06440" class="">before</st> them.

So the God of Israel stirred up King Pul of Assyria (that is, King Tiglath-Pileser of Assyria), and he carried away the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh and took them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and the river of Gozan, where they remain to this very day.
